as I assume path is base class variable it need to be initialized in the initializer list. 
i.e construct base class objects first and then deriver class objects.
reverting as it is member variable and no constructor I guess cannot set
Ack
Just a confusion to be cleared before +1
With the answer provided confusion cleared. +1

I don't see path as a member variable of Entry class then I guess it is a member of the base class it inherits. In that case it is better to initialize this variable via constructor call of the base class in the initializer list itself.
Path is from sdbusplus::xyz::openbmc_project::Common::server::FilePath the interface inherited by this class,
This came up over in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61957 as well so there's a use for this even just with offloading BMC dumps.
Yes,and PLDM also needs this for offloading to host
Add testing details.
Done
Be great to get this repo over to lg2
What is lg2? is it about using std::format?

See mailing details for https://lore.kernel.org/openbmc/YQBrbuQFz4JihBAE@heinlein/

Also you can refer https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/61383 review from implementation point,
It is better  to start migrating to lg2 for newly added files/code. lg2 got better logging capability from debug point.
Update documentation saying it is full path
Done

This concern comes from a discussion with Ed on the associated bmcweb patch for retrieving the dump https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/61957/comment/f1e52fe4_4a7e6e0b/

Should we be exposing a file descriptor instead of a filepath? 
 That's what the xyz.openbmc_project.Logging service does and bmcweb interacts accordingly https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/redfish-core/lib/log_services.hpp#L1960-L1982

There are also discussions around moving bmcweb to non-root.  If that happens then bmcweb won't be able to retrieve the dump from just a filepath.
I think the file descriptor is enough for the current usecase in the PLDM, right @manoj

yes waiting for inputs from PLDM team, to add a new method to retrieve the file handle.

the testcases mentioned are beyond the scope of this commit
Testing completed with PLDM and updated in the commit message
we could as well pass fs::path() to avoid conversion from string to fs::path
Keeping like this will have the advantage not adding a filesystem dependency here
k
we could as well pass fs::path() to avoid conversion from string to fs::path
Keeping like this will have the advantage not adding a filesystem dependency here
makes sense
path?
Done
not on same starting column
Done
should we mention that the caller should not close the fds here as a note.
That is understood and the clients look at the dbus interface documentation not here right?
sdbusplus::message::unix_fd to be consistent
Ack

why can't we use pair here and if multiple clients call getFileHandle we can return the same fd?

also assuming we are using map and we call 3 times then there will be 3 fds in this map, now when the entry is deleted it will try to iterate through the map and as part of delete it will call closeFD which will reset the element of the map it invalidates the iterator, probably the delete method of entry interface should have a logic to delete elements in order.

if we use std::pair we will have only 1 fd and we will not have this issue.
If we are going to maintain file handle for ever then we should make closeFD method private, do not see why users need to call closeFD
ya will modify to return same fd, so map wont be needed
dbusplus::message::unix_fd to be consistent
not critical but u can change if required
Will keep it like this
I think the last piece now that you're working on is to get a Tested: in here to confirm the returned fd can be used to read the dump.
Yes, need to test with PLDM that the dump is offloading to host
Tested
A query on FD close
Done
Done from my side with the latest changes. +1

Looks like this commit is blocking phosphor-dbus-interface version bump. @patrick suggested alternate option to unblock version bump, incase required more time on testing. See discord discussion fro details.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/64304

I've done a bit of digging but I don't understand sdeventplus::source::Defer. Will this automatically be called on our next event loop? If so, how do we ensure we don't close this file descriptor before the caller is done with it?

I was also digging on that, Jay is making a pldm change to test this
but when I am testing with busctl getting a different value than in the actual fd

:~# busctl call  xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Manager  /xyz/openbmc_project/dump/bmc/entry/1 xyz.openbmc_project.Dump.Entry GetFileHandle
<6> file handle request <- A debug trace
<6> Request file: /var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/dumps/1/BMCDUMP.13BE990.0000001.20230616083932 <- Requested for this file
<3> Value 11 <-- fd value in the server
h 4 <-- fd value retuned
:~# <6> File closed file: /var/lib/phosphor-debug-collector/dumps/1/BMCDUMP.13BE990.0000001.20230616083932 fd: 11

so there is a mismatch in this number, I may have to ask around

I think I get it now. When we pass the fd back to the caller, it's duplicated. So as soon as we are sure they have the new duplicated fd, we close ours using this Defer callback. They can then close their copy of the fd whenever they are done with it. Tricky stuff.
Should update GetFileHandle d-bus documentation with expected behavior , saying user has to delete this fd after usage.
The dup of this fd is returned to the caller, and this fd is closed here, I couldnt find such a statement in other dbus definitions returning a unix_fd
who is responsible for deleting the duplicate fd?

You're correct that closing the fd returned by the caller is specific to the sdbusplus implementation. It is a general behavior for any interface returning a unix_fd and not specific to this particular interface.

Since this implementation does not perform the duping of the fd and this interface does not specify how the fd should be handled, I don't believe it is necessary to add generic information about fd deletion to this interface documentation.

However, if it is deemed necessary to provide guidance on fd deletion, it would be more appropriate to document it at a higher level

If we are closing the FD on our own and any client try to close it on their side separately then what would be the result? Can we do something like
const sdbusplus::message::unix_fd& Entry::getFileHandle() where we take fd as std::unique_ptr<int> fd; ?

what is the advantage of having std::unique_ptr<int> fd when returning across dbus?

and in the client implementations,  clients dup the fd and close it independently so the fd opened by this function will be closed by this function.
this is a D-Bus method cannot return unique_ptr
Tested good with pldm changes
